main_entry_content:
OTHER NAMES:
n-Butane
FORMULA:
C4H10
ELEMENTS:
Carbon, hydrogen
COMPOUND TYPE:
Alkane; saturated
hydrocarbon
(organic)
STATE:
Gas
MOLECULAR WEIGHT:
58.12 g/mol
MELTING POINT:
138.3C (216.9F)
BOILING POINT:
0.5C (31F)
SOLUBILITY:
Slightly soluble in
water; soluble in
ethyl alcohol, ether,
and chloroform
Butane
K E Y F A C T S
OVERVIEW
Butane (BYOO-tane) is a colorless gas with the odor of
natural gas that is highly flammable and explosive. It exists
in two isomeric forms. Isomers are forms of a chemical com-
pound with the same molecular formula (in this case, C4H10),
but different structural arrangements. In one isomer (‘normal’
or ‘n-’ butane), the four carbon atoms are arranged in a con-
tinuous chain, while in the other (‘iso-butane’), three carbon
atoms are arranged in a continuous chain and the fourth
carbon atom is attached to the middle atom in that chain.
Butane occurs naturally in natural gas, where it is pre-
sent to the extent of about 1 percent, and in petroleum,
where it exists only in very small amounts. Butane is used
primarily as a fuel and as a chemical intermediary, a com-
pound used to produce other chemical substances.
HOW IT IS MADE
Butane is obtained during the separation of natural gas
into its components. Natural gas consists primarily (70 to
